title: After class 12, what should I study to become an astronaut? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to NASA Astronaut requirements have changed with NASA's goals and missions. A pilot's license and engineering experience is still one route a person could take to becoming an astronaut, but it’s no longer the only one. Today, to be considered for an astronaut position, U.S. citizens must meet the following qualifications: A bachelor's degree in engineering, biological science, physical science, computer science or mathematics.At least three years of related professional experience obtained after degree completion OR at least 1,000 hours pilot-in-command time on jet aircraft.The ability to pass the NASA long-duration astronaut physical. Distant and near visual acuity must be correctable to 20/20 for each eye. The use of glasses is acceptableAnd maybe some few additional requirements like teamwork, persistence and resilience

It is subjective to what agency you’d plan on joining, but the most common options are: Biological science,Computer science,Physical sciences,Or Engineering.Current NASA requirements state that you need to achieve at least a Bachelor’s Degree in one of these fields. In addition to this, NASA asks for 3 years of experience, equivalent to either 1,000 hours of piloting a jet, or a Doctorate in your chosen field (teaching also counts towards experience) before you apply for the position. Hope this helped, For more info, check out this brochure (https://www.nasa.gov/centers/johnson/pdf/606877main_FS-2011-11-057-JSC-astro_trng.pdf) that NASA published; it should provide you with all the info you’ll need. Good luck!
